facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 94 to 97 of 1960 are appeals from the judgment and order dated March 15, 1956, of the Allahabad High Court in First Appeals Nos. 172, 364, and 379 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 94 to 97 of 1960. Appeals from the judgment and order dated March 15, 1956, of the Allahabad High Court in First Appeals Nos. 172, 364, and 379 of 1954.

facts.text: The plaintiff Kundanlal and the defendants 1 to 5 Banarsi Das, Kanshi Ram, Kundan Lal, Munnalal, Devi Chand and Sheo Prasad are brothers and formed a joint Hindu Family till the year 1936.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff Kundanlal and the defendants 1 to 5 Banarsi Das, Kanshi Ram, Kundan Lal, Munnalal, Devi Chand and Sheo Prasad are brothers and formed a joint Hindu Family, till the year 1936.

facts.text: The family owned a sugar mill at Bijnor in Uttar Pradesh called Sheo Prasad Banarsi das Sugar Mills.

anchor.surface_text: Amongst other properties the family owned a sugar mill at Bijnor in Uttar Pradesh called Sheo Prasad Banarsi das Sugar Mills.

facts.text: After the disruption of the family in 1936, the brothers decided to carry on the business of the sugar mill as partners at will with equal shares in profits and losses.

anchor.surface_text: After the disruption of the family the brothers decided to carry on the business of the said sugar mill as partners instead of as members of -a joint Hindu Family. The partnership was to be at will and each of the brothers was to share all the profits and losses equally.

facts.text: For the year 1936-37 beginning September 1, 1936, Banarsi Das was the managing partner.

anchor.surface_text: the agreement arrived at amongst the brothers provided that for the year 1936-37, which began on September 1,1936, the first defendant Banarsi Das, who is the appellant in Civil Appeals 94 to 96 of 1960, was to be the managing partner.

facts.text: For the years 1941-44, Kundanlal was the managing partner.

anchor.surface_text: For the years 1941-44, Kundanlal was the managing partner.

facts.text: On May 13, 1944, Sheo Prasad defendant No. 5 instituted a suit in the court of the Subordinate Judge, First Class, Lahore, for dissolution of partnership and rendition of accounts against Kundanlal and joined the other brothers as defendants.

anchor.surface_text: On May 13,1944, Sheo Prasad defendant No. 5 number deceased, instituted a suit in the companyrt of the Sub- ordinate judge, First Class, Lahore, for dissolution of partnership and rendition of accounts against Kundanlal and joined the other brothers as defendants to the suit,

facts.text: On August 3, 1944, the court appointed Mr. P.C. Mahajan as Receiver in the Lahore suit.

anchor.surface_text: In the companyrse of that suit the companyrt, by its order dated August 3,1944, appointed one Mr. P.C.Mahajan, Pleader, as Receiver

facts.text: High Court of Lahore appointed Kanshiram as Receiver in place of Mr. Mahajan as from April 5, 1945.

anchor.surface_text: In pursuance of the agreement between the parties the High Court appointed Kanshiram as Receiver in place of Mr. Mahajan as from April 5,1945.

facts.text: District Magistrate, Bijnor took over the mill under Defence of India Rules and appointed Kundanlal and his son as agents for U.P. Government for 1944-45, renewed for 1945-46.

anchor.surface_text: In the meanwhile, the District Magistrate, Bijnor took over the mill under the Defence of India Rules and appointed Kundanlal and his son to work the mill as agents of the U. P. Government for the year 1944-45. This lease was renewed by the Government for the year 1945 46.

facts.text: On August 28, 1946, parties except Devi Chand applied to Lahore court for Receiver to execute lease to Banarsidas for five years; court ordered accordingly.

anchor.surface_text: On August 28,1956, the parties, except Devi Chand, made an application to the Court at Lahore praying that the Receiver be ordered to execute a lease in favour of Banarsidas for a period of five years.

facts.text: In September 1946, Banarsidas obtained possession of the mill.

anchor.surface_text: In September 1946, Banarsidas obtained possession of the mill.

facts.text: On October 11, 1947, the Lahore suit was dismissed for default due to partition migration.

anchor.surface_text: On October II, 1947, the Lahore suit was dismissed for default, the parties having migrated to India companysequent on the partition -of the companyntry.

facts.text: On November 8, 1947, Sheo Prasad instituted suit in Civil Judge Bijnor against brothers for injunction against Banarsidas acting as Receiver; dismissed March 3, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: On November 8,1947, Sheo Prasad instituted a suit before the companyrt of Civil judge, Bijnor against his brothers for a permanent injunction restraining Banarsidas from acting as Receiver. The suit, how- ever, was dismissed on March 3,1948.

facts.text: On July 16, 1948, Sheo Prasad transferred his 1/6th share to Banarsidas.

anchor.surface_text: On July 16, 1948, Sheo Prasad transferred his 1/6th share to Banarsidas and since then Banarsidas has been getting the profits both in respect of his own share as well as in respect of that of Sheo Prasad.

facts.text: On October 7, 1948, Kundanlal instituted suit against all brothers claiming dissolution declaration from May 13, 1944, accounts, receiver.

anchor.surface_text: On October 7,1948, the suit out of which these appeals arise was instituted by Kundanlal against all his brothers claiming the reliefs set out in para 29 of the plaint.

facts.text: On July 30, 1949, Banarsidas filed his written statement.

anchor.surface_text: On July 30, 1949 , Banarsidas filed his written statement but numbere of the other dependents put in an appearance.

facts.text: On December 18, 1950, application for receiver dismissed as Kanshi Ram continues as receiver.

anchor.surface_text: On Decemberl8,1950, an application which had been made for the appointment of a Receiver was dismissed on the ground that kanshi Ram who had been appointed as Receiver by the Lahore High Court companytinued to be the Receiver.

facts.text: On April 26, 1951, Mr. Mathur was appointed Receiver by the court.

anchor.surface_text: On April 26 1951, one Mr. Mathur was appointed Receiver by the companyrt

facts.text: Trial court decreed suit on April 2, 1954, declaring partnership dissolved from May 13, 1944, shares 1/6th each, accounts from Kanshi Ram, Mathur continue receiver, Kashi Nath commissioner for winding up.

anchor.surface_text: In view of this companycession by the plaintiff, the Court decreed the suit in the following terms The suit is decreed for declaration that the S. B. Sugar Mills, Bijnor, stood dissolved with effect from 13th May, 1944.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court by judgment dated March 15, 1956 dismissed appeals of Banarsidas and Munnalal, partially allowed Kanshi Ram's appeal, holding suit for accounts and assets distribution barred by limitation Art. 106.

anchor.surface_text: These appeals were heard together and were disposed of by a companymon judgment by the High Court on March 15, 1958. The High Court, in effect, dismissed the appeals of Banarsidas and Munnalal but granted partially the appeal of Kanshi Ram.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on December 17, 1962 by Mudholkar J., allowing appeals and restoring trial court decree.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. December 17. The judgment of the Court was delivered by MUDHOLKAR, j.-These are appeals by certificates granted by the High Court of Allahabad under Art. 133  1   c  of the Constitution from its judgments dated March 15,1956.

facts.text: Banarsidas admitted in written statement that partnership dissolved on May 13, 1944.

anchor.surface_text: No doubt, as pointed out by the High Court, Banarsidas has admitted this fact in his written statement at numberless than three places.

facts.text: Partnership was at will.

anchor.surface_text: It is an admitted fact that the partnership was at will.
under Art. 133  1   c  of the Constitution from its judgments dated March 15,1956.

issues.text: whether the suit was barred by limitation

anchor.surface_text: The most important point to be considered is whether the suit was barred by limitation. If the appellants in these appeals succeed on this point, the first, second and fifth points will really not arise for consideration.

issues.text: Under the Partnership Act, the partners are entitled to have the business of the partnership wound up even though a suit for accounts is barred under Art. 106 of the Limitation Act

anchor.surface_text: Under the Partnership Act, the partners are entitled to have the business of the partnership wound up even though a suit for accounts is barred under Art. 106 of the Limitation Act.

issues.text: Kanshi Ram having been appointed a Receiver by the Court stood in a fiduciary relationship to the other partners and the assets which were in his possession must be deemed to have been held by him for the benefit of all the partners. Therefore, independently of any other consideration, he was bound to render accounts

anchor.surface_text: Kanshi Ram having been appointed a Receiver by the Court stood in a fiduciary relationship to the other partners and the assets which were in his possession must be deemed to have been held by him for the benefit of all the partners.

issues.text: The question of limitation was not raised in the plaint or the grounds of appeal before the High Court and as it is a mixed question of fact and law, it should not have been made the foundation of the decision of the High Court

anchor.surface_text: the question of limitation was not one purely of law but was a mixed question of fact and law, it should not have been made the foundation of the decision of the High Court.

issues.text: If it was thought necessary to allow the point to be raised in view of the provisions of s. 3 of the Limitation Act, the courts should at least have followed the provisions of O. 41, r. 25, Code of Civil Procedure, and framed an issue on the point and remitted it for a finding to the trial court

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, however, resorted to O. 41, r. 33 of the Code of Civil Procedure and held that under this provision, it was competent to it to disallow the claim decreed by the trial court.

issues.text: whether the mere institution of a suit for dissolution dissolves a partnership at will

anchor.surface_text: It is an admitted fact that the partnership was at will. Even so, Mr. Veda Vyasa points out, the mere filing of a suit for dissolution of such a partnership does not amount to a notice for dissolution of the partnership.

arguments.claim: analogy to partition suit: suit severs joint status

anchor.surface_text: The argument seems to be based on the analogy of suits for partition of joint Hindu family property, with regard to which it is settled law that if all the parties are majors, the institution of a suit for partition will result in the severance of the joint status of the members of the family.

arguments.claim: High Court should not have allowed new limitation plea by non-contesting defendants

anchor.surface_text: We do not think that this was a fit case for permitting an entirely new point to be raised by a non-contesting party to the suit.

holdings.text: The suit is not barred by limitation as the High Court erred in holding so.

anchor.surface_text: Since that date is not known or could have been known by the High Court, it was in error in holding that the suit was barred by time.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dissolution date not May 13, 1944; no evidence of notice communication dates; limitation start uncertain.

holdings.text: Mere institution of a suit for dissolution does not dissolve a partnership at will.

anchor.surface_text: It is an admitted fact that the partnership was at will. Even so, Mr. Veda Vyasa points out, the mere filing of a suit for dissolution of such a partnership does not amount to a notice for dissolution of the partnership.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Requires notice in writing under s.43(1); suit filing not equivalent; cites Corpus Juris and O.20 r.15 CPC.

holdings.text: A plaint in a suit for dissolution does not constitute 'notice in writing' under s.43(1) of the Partnership Act.

anchor.surface_text: Mentioning of such a date would be entirely foreign to a plaint in a suit for dissolution of partnership and therefore such a plaint cannot fall within the expression notice used in the Sub-Section.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plaint lacks specific dissolution date; s.43(2) requires date in notice or communication thereof; analogy to partition suits rejected.

holdings.text: An admission in pleadings binds only as to facts, not as to questions of law.

anchor.surface_text: No doubt, as pointed out by the High Court, Banarsidas has admitted this fact in his written statement at no less than three places. The admission, however, would bind him only in so far as facts are concerned but not in so far as it relates to a question of law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dissolution date is legal conclusion, not pure fact; admission on fact of suit filing doesn't bind on legal effect.

holdings.text: Plea of limitation is a mixed question of fact and law and cannot be raised for the first time in appeal without opportunity to parties.

anchor.surface_text: the question of limitation was not one purely of law but was a mixed question of fact and law and, therefore, it was not proper for it to allow it to be raised for the first time in argument.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Requires evidence on notice service dates; caused prejudice; no prior pleading.

holdings.text: High Court should have framed issue on limitation and remitted to trial court under O.41 r.25 CPC instead of deciding itself.

anchor.surface_text: If the High Court felt overwhelmed by the provisions of s. 3 of the limitation Act, it should at least have given an opportunity to the parties... framed an issue and remitted it for a finding to the trial Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.3 duty doesn't override procedural fairness; allow amendment, evidence on facts like summons service.

holdings.text: High Court erred in permitting entirely new limitation plea by non-contesting parties who filed no written statement.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No contest in trial; surprise prejudiced parties; no opportunity for counter like acknowledgments.

holdings.text: High Court decision set aside; trial court decree restored declaring partnership dissolved from May 13, 1944, shares 1/6th each, accounts from Kanshi Ram, receiver and commissioner continue.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural errors on limitation plea warrant reversal; restores winding up, accounts, etc.

justification_sets.label: Mixed Question of Fact and Law support

anchor.surface_text: For the aforesaid reasons, we allow the appeals of Banarsidas and Kundanlal and restore the decree of the trial court, but make no order as to costs.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeals of Banarsidas (Civil Appeals Nos. 94 to 96 of 1960) and Kundanlal (Civil Appeal No. 97 of 1960) allowed; decree of the trial court restored; High Court decision set aside
